title: 111_hr3779
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Fairness Act of 2009" extends and expands the homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Fairness Act of 2009" extends and expands the homebuyer tax credit by repealing the first-time homebuyer requirement in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This change allows any individual who purchases a principal residence to qualify for the tax credit. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Fairness Act of 2009" expands the homebuyer tax credit by increasing the dollar limitation to $15,000 and repealing the income phaseout requirement. Additionally, a waiver of recapture is provided for individuals on qualified official extended duty, including members of the armed forces. The special rule for members of the armed forces and individuals on qualified official extended duty exempts them from certain tax provisions when disposing of a principal residence after December 31, 2008. For qualified official extended duty service, the special rule exempts members of the uniformed services, Foreign Service of the United States, or employees of the intelligence community from certain tax provisions when disposing of a principal residence. The amendments made to the tax code extend the credit deadline to December 1, 2010, and apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2008. There is a waiver of recapture for individuals on qualified official extended duty after December 31, 2008. The credit deadline extension applies to dispositions and cessations after December 31, 2008, and to purchases after November 30, 2009. All unobligated discretionary funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 are rescinded by this Act.
